informal_statement:
Kanel-Belov A.Y.
The sum of the digits of a natural number $n$ is 100. Can the sum of the digits of the number $n^{3}$ be 1000000?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Kanel-Belov A.Y.
The sum of the digits of a natural number $n$ is 100. Can the sum of the digits of the number $n^{3}$ be 1000000? -/
theorem number_theory_237210 :
    ∃ n, (Nat.digits 10 n).sum = 100 ∧ (Nat.digits 10 (n ^ 3)).sum = 1000000 := by

soln_description:
10.49 We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|z^{3}+z^{5}\right|=|\cos 3 \alpha+i \sin 3 \alpha+\cos 5 \alpha+i \sin 5 \alpha|= \\
& =|\cos 3 \alpha+\cos 5 \alpha+i(\sin 3 \alpha+\sin 5 \alpha)|= \\
& =\sqrt{4 \cos ^{2} 4 \alpha \cos ^{2} \alpha+4 \sin ^{2} 4 \alpha \cos ^{2} \alpha}= \\
& =\sqrt{4 \cos ^{2} \alpha}=2|\cos \alpha|, \text { since } \alpha \in\left(\pi, \frac{3 \pi}{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Answer: $2|\cos \alpha|$.
informal_statement: 10.49 Find the modulus of the complex number $z^{3}+z^{5}$, if $z=\cos \alpha+i \sin \alpha, \alpha \in\left(\pi, \frac{3 \pi}{2}\right)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 10.49 Find the modulus of the complex number $z^{3}+z^{5}$, if $z=\cos \alpha+i \sin \alpha, \alpha \in\left(\pi, \frac{3 \pi}{2}\right)$. -/
theorem algebra_180863 (α : ℝ) (hα : α ∈ Set.Ioo Real.pi (3 * Real.pi / 2)) (z : ℂ)
    (hz : z = Complex.exp (Complex.I * α)) :
    Complex.abs (z^3 + z^5) = 2 * abs (Real.cos α) := by

soln_description:
[Solution 1] If the cube of a positive integer ends in 8, then this number itself must end in 2, i.e., it can be written as
$$
n=10 k+2 \text { ( } k \text { is a non-negative integer) }
$$

Thus,
$$
\begin{aligned}
n^{3} & =(10 k+2)^{3} \\
& =1000 k^{3}+600 k^{2}+120 k+8 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, $120 k$ determines the tens digit of $n^{3}$. Since it is required that the tens digit of $n^{3}$ is 8, then the units digit of $12 k$ should be 8, i.e., the units digit of $k$ is 4 or 9, so we can set
$$
k=5 m+4 \text { ( } m \text { is a non-negative integer). }
$$

At this time, $n^{3}=[10(5 m+4)+2]^{3}$
$$
=125000 m^{3}+315000 m^{2}+264600 m+74088 \text {. }
$$

To make the hundreds digit of $n^{3}$ be 8, it is necessary that the units digit of $2646 m$ is 8, the smallest $m=3$.
At this time
$$
\begin{array}{c}
k=5 m+4=19, \\
n=10 k+2=192 .
\end{array}
$$

We can find that $n^{3}=7077888$, its last three digits are 888.
Therefore, the smallest $n$ is 192.
[Solution 2] By the problem, we have
$$
1000 \mid n^{3}-888
$$

So
$$
\begin{array}{c}
1000 \mid n^{3}+112-1000, \\
1000 \mid n^{3}+112 .
\end{array}
$$

So $n$ is even, let $n=2 k$, then
$$
1000 \mid 8 k^{3}+112=8\left(k^{3}+14\right) \text {. }
$$

This requires
$$
125 \mid k^{3}+14 \text {. }
$$

First, it must be $5 \mid k^{3}+14$, so the units digit of $k$ is 6 or 1.
Thus, we can set $k=5 m+1$ ( $m$ is a non-negative integer)
$$
\begin{aligned}
k^{3}+14 & =(5 m+1)^{3}+14 \\
& =125 m^{3}+75 m^{2}+15 m+15 \\
& =5\left(25 m^{3}+15 m^{2}+3 m+3\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

To make $125 \mid k^{3}+14$, it is only necessary that
$$
25 \mid 15 m^{2}+3 m+3 \text {. }
$$

Thus, the units digit of $15 m^{2}+3 m+3$ is 0 or 5, since
$$
15 m^{2}+3 m+3=3 m(5 m+1)+3 \text {. }
$$
$m(5 m+1)$ is definitely even, so the units digit of $3 m(5 m+1)$ is definitely 2. Thus, the units digit of $m(5 m+1)$ must be 4, at this time the units digit of $m$ must be 4 or 9. For this, set $m=5 t+4,(t$ is a non-negative integer $)$.
$$
\begin{aligned}
& 15 m^{2}+3 m+3 \\
= & 15(5 t+4)^{2}+3(5 t+4)+3 \\
= & 15 \cdot 25 t^{2}+40 \cdot 15 t+16 \cdot 15+15 t+15 \\
= & 15 \cdot 25 t^{2}+24 \cdot 25 t+15 t+15 \cdot 17
\end{aligned}
$$

To make $25 \mid 15 m^{2}+3 m+3$, it is only necessary that
i.e.,
$$
\begin{array}{c}
25 \mid 15 t+15 \cdot 17, \\
5 \mid 3 t+51 .
\end{array}
$$

Take the smallest $t=3$.
Then $\quad m=5 t+4=19, k=5 m+1=96$.
Thus $\quad n=2 k=192$.
informal_statement:
$1 \cdot 32$ Find the smallest positive integer $n$, such that the last three digits of its cube are 888.
(6th American Invitational Mathematics Examination, 1988)
informal_proof:
We aim to demonstrate that $192$ is the smallest positive integer $n$ satisfying the condition $n^3 \equiv 888 \pmod{1000}$.

First, we establish that $192$ is indeed an element of the set $\{n \mid 0 < n \land n^3 \equiv 888 \pmod{1000}\}$.
1.  We verify that $192 > 0$.
2.  We verify that $192^3 \equiv 888 \pmod{1000}$.

Next, we prove that $192$ is the least element in this set. We proceed by contradiction. Assume there exists a positive integer $n$ such that $n < 192$ and $n^3 \equiv 888 \pmod{1000}$.
This implies that $n$ is in the range $0 \leq n < 192$.

The proof then systematically checks each integer $n$ in the range $[0, 191]$. For every such $n$, it is shown that the condition $n^3 \equiv 888 \pmod{1000}$ does not hold. Each of these checks results in a contradiction. Therefore, our initial assumption that a smaller positive integer $n$ satisfies the condition must be false.

Consequently, $192$ is the smallest positive integer satisfying the given property.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $1 \cdot 32$ Find the smallest positive integer $n$, such that the last three digits of its cube are 888.
(6th American Invitational Mathematics Examination, 1988) -/
theorem number_theory_99419 : IsLeast {n | 0 < n ∧ (n ^ 3) % 1000 = 888} 192 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_99419 : IsLeast {n | 0 < n ∧ (n ^ 3) % 1000 = 888} 192 := by
  constructor 
  · -- Show 192 is in the set
    constructor
    · -- Show 0 < 192
      norm_num 
    · -- Show 192^3 % 1000 = 888
      norm_num 
  · -- Show that 192 is the least 
    intro n hn
    rcases hn with ⟨hn_pos, hn_cube⟩

    by_contra h
    push_neg at h 
    have h' : n < 192 := h 
    interval_cases n <;> norm_num at hn_cube <;> all_goals omega

soln_description: Solution. If $k$ is a natural number, $1 \leq k2$. This means that the number of irreducible fractions is even.
informal_statement: 1. If $n$ is a natural number greater than 2, prove that among the fractions $\frac{1}{n}, \frac{2}{n}, \frac{3}{n}, \ldots, \frac{n-1}{n}$ there is an even number of irreducible fractions.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. If $n$ is a natural number greater than 2, prove that among the fractions $\frac{1}{n}, \frac{2}{n}, \frac{3}{n}, \ldots, \frac{n-1}{n}$ there is an even number of irreducible fractions. -/
theorem number_theory_220005 (n : ℕ) (hn : n > 2) :
    Even {k | k ∈ Finset.Icc 1 (n - 1) ∧ Nat.Coprime k n}.ncard := by

soln_description:
Answer: $7 \times 4$ and $1 \times 21$ or $1 \times 33$ and $1 \times 16$.

Solution. The sum of their areas is 49 ($28+21$ in the first case and $33+16$ in the second), and their perimeters indeed differ by a factor of 2: in the first case $2 \cdot(7+4)=22$, $2 \cdot(1+21)=44$; in the second $2 \cdot(1+16)=34, 2 \cdot(1+33)=68$.

Criteria. A correct example is provided without calculations showing that it fits - 5 points. At least one of the sides is not an integer - 0 points.
informal_statement:
2. There are 49 identical squares. Form two rectangles from them so that their perimeters differ by a factor of 2. No squares should be left over.

(L. S. Koreschkova)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. There are 49 identical squares. Form two rectangles from them so that their perimeters differ by a factor of 2. No squares should be left over.

(L. S. Koreschkova) -/
theorem number_theory_284884 (a b c d : ℕ) (h₀ : a > 0) (h₁ : b > 0) (h₂ : c > 0)
    (h₃ : d > 0) (h₄ : a * b + c * d = 49) (h₅ : 2 * (a + b) = 3 * (c + d)) :
    (a = 7 ∧ b = 41 ∧ c = 21) ∨ (a = 1 ∧ b = 331 ∧ c = 16) := by

informal_statement:
2. The equation about $x$
$$
x^{2}-2 a x+a^{2}-4 a=0
$$

has an imaginary root with a modulus of 3. Then the value of the real number $a$ is $\qquad$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. The equation about $x$
$$
x^{2}-2 a x+a^{2}-4 a=0
$$

has an imaginary root with a modulus of 3. Then the value of the real number $a$ is $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_317146 (a : ℝ) (h : ∃ z : ℂ, z^2 - 2*a*z + a^2 - 4*a = 0 ∧ ‖z‖ = 3) :
    a = 2 - Real.sqrt 13 := by

soln_description:
Answer: 13 or 20.

Solution. Let the graph of the function $y=a x+4$ be denoted by $l_{1}$, the function $y=2 x+b-$ by $l_{2}$, and the function $y=\frac{a}{2} x+8-$ by $l_{3}$.

From the condition, it follows that $l_{1}, l_{2}, l_{3}$ are pairwise intersecting lines (each of the points $A, B, C$ belongs to some two of them). Immediately note that the case $a=0$ is impossible, otherwise the lines $y=a x+4$ and $y=\frac{a}{2} x+8$ would be parallel.

Point $C$ lies on the $O y$ axis, as well as on two of the three given lines. This means that their equations, when substituting $x=0$, give the same values (equal to the ordinate of point $C$). Therefore, $C$ cannot be the intersection point of lines $l_{1}$ and $l_{3}$.

It is easy to see that the line $l_{1}$ intersects the $O y$ axis at the point $-\frac{4}{a}$, the line $l_{2}$ at the point $-\frac{b}{2}$, and the line $l_{3}$ at the point $\frac{-16}{a}$. Among these three numbers, there are two identical ones (equal to the abscissa of point B). Clearly, $-\frac{4}{a} \neq \frac{-16}{a}$, so there are two possible cases.

- Suppose $-\frac{4}{a}=-\frac{b}{2}$, i.e., $l_{1}$ and $l_{2}$ intersect at point $B$. Then $C$ is the intersection point of lines $l_{2}$ and $l_{3}$, i.e., their equations at $x=0$ coincide, and $b=8$. From the equality $-\frac{4}{a}=-\frac{b}{2}$, we get that $a=1$. Then $A$ is the intersection point of $l_{1}$ and $l_{3}$, which are the graphs of the functions $y=x+4$ and $y=\frac{1}{2} x+8$. It is easy to understand that these two lines intersect at the point $(8 ; 12)$, so the answer in this case is $8+12=20$.
- Suppose $-\frac{b}{2}=-\frac{16}{a}$, i.e., $l_{2}$ and $l_{3}$ intersect at point $B$. Then $C$ is the intersection point of lines $l_{1}$ and $l_{2}$, i.e., their equations at $x=0$ coincide, and $b=4$. From the equality $-\frac{b}{2}=-\frac{16}{a}$, we get that $a=8$. Then $A$ is the intersection point of $l_{1}$ and $l_{3}$, which are the graphs of the functions $y=8 x+4$ and $y=4 x+8$. It is easy to understand that these two lines intersect at the point $(1 ; 12)$, so the answer in this case is $1+12=13$.
informal_statement:
Problem 9.7. On the coordinate plane, there is a point $A$. On the $O x$ axis, there is a point $B$, and on the $O y$ axis, there is a point $C$.

It is known that the equations of the lines $A B, B C, A C$ in some order have the form $y=a x+4$, $y=2 x+b$ and $y=\frac{a}{2} x+8$ for some real numbers $a$ and $b$.

Find the sum of the coordinates of point $A$. Specify all possible values.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Problem 9.7. On the coordinate plane, point $A$ is marked. On the $O x$ axis, point $B$ is marked, and on the $O y$ axis, point $C$ is marked.

It is known that the equations of the lines $A B, B C, A C$ in some order have the form $y=a x+4$, $y=2 x+b$ and $y=\frac{a}{2} x+8$ for some real numbers $a$ and $b$.

Find the sum of the coordinates of point $A$. Specify all possible values. -/
theorem algebra_107067 (A B C : ℝ × ℝ)
    (hA : A ≠ B) (hB : B ≠ C) (hC : A ≠ C)
    (h1 : ∃ a b, A.1 * a + 4 = B.2 ∧ B.1 * 2 + b = C.2 ∧ A.1 * (a / 2) + 8 = C.2)
    (h2 : ∃ a b, A.1 * 2 + b = B.2 ∧ B.1 * a + 4 = C.2 ∧ A.1 * (a / 2) + 8 = C.2)
    (h3 : ∃ a b, A.1 * (a / 2) + 8 = B.2 ∧ B.1 * a + 4 = C.2 ∧ A.1 * 2 + b = C.2) :
    A.1 + A.2 = 13 ∨ A.1 + A.2 = 20 := by

soln_description:
1. Let's make the substitution $x^{2}+3 x+6=t$. The equation reduces to $ rac{5 x}{t}+ rac{7 x}{t+4 x}=1$, i.e., $5 x t+20 x^{2}+7 x t=t^{2}+4 t x$ (with the conditions $t 
eq 0$ and $t+4 x 
eq 0$), which is equivalent to $t^{2}-8 t x-20 x^{2}=0$. Dividing both sides by $x^{2}$ (with the condition $x^{2} 
eq 0$) the equation further reduces to $\left( rac{t}{x}ight)^{2}-8  rac{t}{x}-20=0$, and by introducing the new substitution $k= rac{t}{x}$ we get $k^{2}-8 k-20=0$. The solutions to this quadratic equation are $k_{1 / 2}= rac{8 \pm \sqrt{8^{2}-4 \cdot(-20)}}{2}= rac{8 \pm \sqrt{144}}{2}= rac{8 \pm 12}{2}$, i.e., $k_{1}= rac{8+12}{2}=10$ and $k_{2}= rac{8-12}{2}=-2$. For $k=10$, after returning the substitution, we have $x^{2}+3 x+6=t=k x=10 x$, i.e., $x^{2}-7 x+6=0$, whose solution gives $x_{1 / 2}= rac{7 \pm \sqrt{(-7)^{2}-4 \cdot 6}}{2}= rac{7 \pm 5}{2}$, i.e., $x_{1}=6$ and $x_{2}=1$. For $k=-2$, after returning the substitution, we have $x^{2}+3 x+6=t=k x=-2 x$, i.e., $x^{2}+5 x+6=0$, whose solution gives $x_{3 / 4}= rac{-5 \pm \sqrt{5^{2}-4 \cdot 6}}{2}= rac{-5 \pm 1}{2}$, i.e., $x_{3}=-2$ and $x_{4}=-3$. All four obtained solutions satisfy the conditions of definition, so they are indeed the solutions to the original equation.
informal_statement:
1. In the set of real numbers, solve the equation:

$$
\frac{5 x}{x^{2}+3 x+6}+\frac{7 x}{x^{2}+7 x+6}=1
$$
informal_proof:
We want to prove the equivalence between the given equation and the condition that \( x \) belongs to the set \(\{6, 1, -2, -3\}\). We will prove this in both directions.

**Forward Direction (\( \implies \))**:
Assume that the equation \( \frac{5 x}{x^{2}+3 x+6}+\frac{7 x}{x^{2}+7 x+6}=1 \) holds, and that the denominators are non-zero, i.e., \( x^2 + 3x + 6 \neq 0 \) and \( x^2 + 7x + 6 \neq 0 \).

To clear the fractions, we multiply both sides of the equation by the product of the denominators, \( (x^2+3x+6)(x^2+7x+6) \). This yields:
$$ 5 x (x^2 + 7x + 6) + 7 x (x^2 + 3x + 6) = (x^2 + 3x + 6)(x^2 + 7x + 6) $$
We can expand both sides of this equation. The left side becomes:
$$ 5x^3 + 35x^2 + 30x + 7x^3 + 21x^2 + 42x = 12x^3 + 56x^2 + 72x $$
The right side becomes:
$$ (x^2)(x^2) + (x^2)(7x) + (x^2)(6) + (3x)(x^2) + (3x)(7x) + (3x)(6) + (6)(x^2) + (6)(7x) + (6)(6) $$
$$ = x^4 + 7x^3 + 6x^2 + 3x^3 + 21x^2 + 18x + 6x^2 + 42x + 36 $$
$$ = x^4 + 10x^3 + 33x^2 + 60x + 36 $$
Equating the expanded left and right sides, we get:
$$ 12x^3 + 56x^2 + 72x = x^4 + 10x^3 + 33x^2 + 60x + 36 $$
Rearranging all terms to one side to form a polynomial equation equal to zero:
$$ x^4 + (10-12)x^3 + (33-56)x^2 + (60-72)x + 36 = 0 $$
$$ x^4 - 2x^3 - 23x^2 - 12x + 36 = 0 $$
This polynomial can be factored. It is equivalent to:
$$ (x - 6)(x + 3)(x + 2)(x - 1) = 0 $$
For this product of terms to be zero, at least one of the factors must be zero. This implies that:
$$ x - 6 = 0 \quad \text{or} \quad x + 3 = 0 \quad \text{or} \quad x + 2 = 0 \quad \text{or} \quad x - 1 = 0 $$
Solving these linear equations for \( x \), we find the possible values for \( x \) are:
$$ x = 6 \quad \text{or} \quad x = -3 \quad \text{or} \quad x = -2 \quad \text{or} \quad x = 1 $$
We must verify that these values do not make the original denominators zero.
For \( x = 6 \): \( x^2+3x+6 = 36+18+6 = 60 \neq 0 \), \( x^2+7x+6 = 36+42+6 = 84 \neq 0 \).
For \( x = 1 \): \( x^2+3x+6 = 1+3+6 = 10 \neq 0 \), \( x^2+7x+6 = 1+7+6 = 14 \neq 0 \).
For \( x = -2 \): \( x^2+3x+6 = 4-6+6 = 4 \neq 0 \), \( x^2+7x+6 = 4-14+6 = -4 \neq 0 \).
For \( x = -3 \): \( x^2+3x+6 = 9-9+6 = 6 \neq 0 \), \( x^2+7x+6 = 9-21+6 = -6 \neq 0 \).
Since all these values of \( x \) satisfy the non-zero denominator conditions and the factored polynomial equation, they must satisfy the original equation. Therefore, if the equation holds, then \( x \in \{6, 1, -2, -3\} \).

**Backward Direction (\( \impliedby \))**:
Now, we assume that \( x \) is one of the values \( 6, 1, -2, \) or \( -3 \) and show that it satisfies the given equation.

*   **Case 1: \( x = 6 \)**
    We check the denominators: \( 6^2 + 3(6) + 6 = 36 + 18 + 6 = 60 \neq 0 \) and \( 6^2 + 7(6) + 6 = 36 + 42 + 6 = 84 \neq 0 \).
    Now, we substitute \( x = 6 \) into the left-hand side of the equation:
    $$ \frac{5(6)}{60} + \frac{7(6)}{84} = \frac{30}{60} + \frac{42}{84} = \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{2} = 1 $$
    The equation holds.

*   **Case 2: \( x = 1 \)**
    We check the denominators: \( 1^2 + 3(1) + 6 = 1 + 3 + 6 = 10 \neq 0 \) and \( 1^2 + 7(1) + 6 = 1 + 7 + 6 = 14 \neq 0 \).
    Now, we substitute \( x = 1 \) into the left-hand side of the equation:
    $$ \frac{5(1)}{10} + \frac{7(1)}{14} = \frac{5}{10} + \frac{7}{14} = \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{2} = 1 $$
    The equation holds.

*   **Case 3: \( x = -2 \)**
    We check the denominators: \( (-2)^2 + 3(-2) + 6 = 4 - 6 + 6 = 4 \neq 0 \) and \( (-2)^2 + 7(-2) + 6 = 4 - 14 + 6 = -4 \neq 0 \).
    Now, we substitute \( x = -2 \) into the left-hand side of the equation:
    $$ \frac{5(-2)}{4} + \frac{7(-2)}{-4} = \frac{-10}{4} + \frac{-14}{-4} = -\frac{5}{2} + \frac{7}{2} = \frac{2}{2} = 1 $$
    The equation holds.

*   **Case 4: \( x = -3 \)**
    We check the denominators: \( (-3)^2 + 3(-3) + 6 = 9 - 9 + 6 = 6 \neq 0 \) and \( (-3)^2 + 7(-3) + 6 = 9 - 21 + 6 = -6 \neq 0 \).
    Now, we substitute \( x = -3 \) into the left-hand side of the equation:
    $$ \frac{5(-3)}{6} + \frac{7(-3)}{-6} = \frac{-15}{6} + \frac{-21}{-6} = -\frac{5}{2} + \frac{7}{2} = \frac{2}{2} = 1 $$
    The equation holds.

In all four cases, the values \( x \in \{6, 1, -2, -3\} \) satisfy both the non-zero denominator conditions and the original equation.

Since we have proven both the forward and backward directions, the equivalence is established.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. In the set of real numbers, solve the equation:

$$
\frac{5 x}{x^{2}+3 x+6}+\frac{7 x}{x^{2}+7 x+6}=1
$$ -/
theorem algebra_106625 (x : ℝ) :
    x^2 + 3 * x + 6 ≠ 0 ∧ x^2 + 7 * x + 6 ≠ 0 ∧
    5 * x / (x^2 + 3 * x + 6) + 7 * x / (x^2 + 7 * x + 6) = 1 ↔
    x = 6 ∨ x = 1 ∨ x = -2 ∨ x = -3 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_106625 (x : ℝ) :
    x^2 + 3 * x + 6 ≠ 0 ∧ x^2 + 7 * x + 6 ≠ 0 ∧
    5 * x / (x^2 + 3 * x + 6) + 7 * x / (x^2 + 7 * x + 6) = 1 ↔
    x = 6 ∨ x = 1 ∨ x = -2 ∨ x = -3 := by
  constructor
  · -- Forward direction: if x satisfies equation then x ∈ {6,1,-2,-3}
    rintro ⟨hx₁, hx₂, heq⟩
    -- Multiply through by denominators to clear fractions:
    -- 5x*(x^2+7x+6) + 7x*(x^2+3x+6) = (x^2+3x+6)(x^2+7x+6)
    have h1 : x^2 + 3 * x + 6 ≠ 0 := hx₁
    have h2 : x^2 + 7 * x + 6 ≠ 0 := hx₂
    have eq1 : 5 * x * (x ^ 2 + 7 * x + 6) + 7 * x * (x ^ 2 + 3 * x + 6) =
          (x^2 + 3 * x + 6) * (x^2 + 7 * x + 6) := by
      have eq2 : 5 * x / (x^2 + 3 * x + 6) + 7 * x / (x^2 + 7 * x + 6) = 1 := heq
      have eq3 : 5 * x / (x^2 + 3 * x + 6) + 7 * x / (x^2 + 7 * x + 6) - 1 = 0 := by
        linarith
      have eq4 : (5 * x / (x^2 + 3 * x + 6) + 7 * x / (x^2 + 7 * x + 6) - 1) =
          ( (5 * x * (x ^ 2 + 7 * x + 6) + 7 * x * (x ^ 2 + 3 * x + 6) - (x^2 + 3 * x + 6) * (x^2 + 7 * x + 6))  ) / ( (x^2 + 3 * x + 6) * (x^2 + 7 * x + 6) ) := by
        field_simp
        <;> ring
      rw [eq4] at eq3
      have eq5 : (5 * x * (x ^ 2 + 7 * x + 6) + 7 * x * (x ^ 2 + 3 * x + 6) - (x^2 + 3 * x + 6) * (x^2 + 7 * x + 6)) / ((x^2 + 3 * x + 6) * (x^2 + 7 * x + 6)) = 0 := eq3
      have eq6 : 5 * x * (x ^ 2 + 7 * x + 6) + 7 * x * (x ^ 2 + 3 * x + 6) - (x^2 + 3 * x + 6) * (x^2 + 7 * x + 6) = 0 := by
        field_simp [(show (x^2 + 3 * x + 6) ≠ 0 by exact hx₁), 
            (show (x^2 + 7 * x + 6) ≠ 0 by exact hx₂)] at eq5 ⊢
        <;> nlinarith [eq5]
      linarith
    have eq2 : x^4 - 2*x^3 - 23*x^2 - 12*x + 36 = 0 := by
      nlinarith [eq1, sq_nonneg (x + 3), sq_nonneg (x + 2), sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (x - 6), sq_nonneg (x^2 - 3*x - 6), sq_nonneg (x^2 +7*x +6)]
    have h3 : (x - 6) * (x + 3) * (x + 2) * (x - 1) = 0 := by
      nlinarith [eq2]
    cases' (mul_eq_zero.mp h3) with h4 h4
    cases' (mul_eq_zero.mp h4) with h4 h4
    cases' (mul_eq_zero.mp h4) with h4 h4
    · -- Case x - 6 = 0 → x = 6
      left
      linarith
    · -- Case x + 3 = 0 → x = -3
      right
      right
      right
      linarith
    · -- Case x + 2 = 0 → x = -2
      right
      right
      left
      linarith
    · -- Case x - 1 = 0 → x = 1
      right
      left
      linarith
  · -- Backward direction: each of these x satisfy the equation
    rintro (rfl | rfl | rfl | rfl)
    · constructor
      · norm_num
      · constructor
        · norm_num
        · norm_num
    · constructor
      · norm_num
      · constructor
        · norm_num
        · norm_num
    · constructor
      · norm_num
      · constructor
        · norm_num
        · norm_num
    · constructor
      · norm_num
      · constructor
        · norm_num
        · norm_num

soln_description:
# Solution:

From the condition:
$m_{C T}=\frac{m_{C T}+m_{M}}{3}$, i.e. $m_{M}=2 m_{C T}$

(5 points)

$10 \cdot V_{C T}=V_{M}$

(5 points)

## Therefore, the density:

$\rho_{M}=\frac{m_{M}}{V_{M}}=\frac{2 m_{C T}}{10 V_{C T}}=0.2 \rho_{C T}$
informal_statement:
# Problem №2 (15 points)

An empty glass jar is three times lighter than the same jar filled to the brim with milk. If it is known that the volume occupied by the glass is ten times less than the volume occupied by the milk, then compare the densities of glass and milk. The density of a material is defined as the ratio of the mass of the material to its volume.

#
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- # Problem №2 (15 points)

An empty glass jar is three times lighter than the same jar filled to the brim with milk. If it is known that the volume occupied by the glass is ten times less than the volume occupied by the milk, then compare the densities of glass and milk. The density of a material is defined as the ratio of the mass of the material to its volume.

# -/
theorem algebra_169520 {ρ : ℝ} (hρ : ρ > 0) (h : (1 / 3) * ρ = (1 / 10) * (ρ + m)) :
    ρ / m = 0.2 := by

soln_description:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { II. Let } a+b+c=x, b+c+d=y, \\
c+d+a=z, d+a+b=w .
\end{array}
$$

Then the original expression
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\Leftrightarrow \sum \frac{(z-y)(w-y)}{x} \geqslant 0 \\
\Leftrightarrow \sum y z w(z-y)(w-y) \geqslant 0 \\
\Leftrightarrow L(z-x)^{2}+M(z-x)(w-z)+N(w-y)^{2} \geqslant 0,
\end{array}
$$

where, $L=x w z$,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
M=(x-y)(x z+w y-w z), \\
N=w x y .
\end{array}
$$

Notice that,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
|M|=|d-a|\left(c^{2}+b^{2}+2 a c+2 b d+d c+a b+b c\right) \\
\leqslant|d-a|(a+b+c)(c+b+d) \\
=2|a-b| x y \\
|a-d|^{2} y<(b+c+d)\left(a^{2}+d^{2}\right) \\
<\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+d^{2}+2 a b+2 a d+2 b d\right)(c+d+a) \\
=w^{2} z
\end{array}
$$

Then $M^{2} \leqslant 4 L N$.
Therefore, the original inequality holds.
informal_statement:
II. (40 points) Given $a, b, c, d \in \mathbf{R}_{+}$. Prove:
$$
\sum \frac{(a-b)(a-c)}{a+b+c} \geqslant 0,
$$

where, $\sum$ denotes the cyclic sum.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- II. (40 points) Given $a, b, c, d \in \mathbf{R}_{+}$. Prove:
$$
\sum \frac{(a-b)(a-c)}{a+b+c} \geqslant 0,
$$

where, $\sum$ denotes the cyclic sum. -/
theorem inequalities_320640 (a b c d : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) (hd : 0 < d) :
    (a - b) * (a - c) / (a + b + c) + (b - c) * (b - d) / (b + c + d) +
    (c - d) * (c - a) / (c + d + a) + (d - a) * (d - b) / (d + a + b) ≥ 0 := by

informal_statement:
Given that $\alpha $, $\beta $ are the two distinct real roots of the equation $4{{x}^{2}}-4tx-1=0(t\in \mathbf{R})$, and the function $f(x)=\frac{2x-t}{{{x}^{2}}+1}$ has a domain of $\left[ \alpha ,\beta \right]$.


Find $g(t)=\max f(x)-\min f(x)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Given that $\alpha $, $\beta $ are the two distinct real roots of the equation $4{{x}^{2}}-4tx-1=0(t\in \mathbf{R})$, and the function $f(x)=\frac{2x-t}{{{x}^{2}}+1}$ has a domain of $\left[ \alpha ,\beta \right]$.


Find $g(t)=\max f(x)-\min f(x)$. -/
theorem algebra_9399 (t : ℝ) (α β : ℝ) (f : ℝ → ℝ)
    (h₁ : α ≠ β) (h₂ : 4 * α ^ 2 - 4 * t * α - 1 = 0) (h₃ : 4 * β ^ 2 - 4 * t * β - 1 = 0)
    (h₄ : ∀ x ∈ Set.Icc α β, f x = (2 * x - t) / (x ^ 2 + 1)) :
    IsGreatest (Set.image f (Set.Icc α β)) (8 * Real.sqrt (t ^ 2 + 1) * (2 * t ^ 2 + 5) / (16 * t ^ 2 + 25)) ∧
    IsLeast (Set.image f (Set.Icc α β)) 0 := by

soln_description:
Solution:

1) $x=\frac{\pi k}{1008}, k \in \mathbb{Z}, k$ does not divide 1008.
2) $x=\frac{\pi+4 \pi k}{4032}, k \in \mathbb{Z}$.

Proof:

First, let's prove the following formulas by induction in the case where $\sin x \neq 0$:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sum_{k=1}^{n} \sin ((2 k-1) x)=\frac{\sin ^{2}(n x)}{\sin x} \\
\sum_{k=1}^{n} \cos ((2 k-1) x)=\frac{\sin (2 n x)}{2 \sin x}=\frac{\sin (n x) \cos (n x)}{\sin x}
\end{gathered}
$$

First formula. Base case $n=1: \sin x=\frac{\sin ^{2} x}{\sin x}$ - a true statement.

Inductive step: Assume the statement is true for some $n$, we will prove that it is also true for $n+1$.

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sum_{k=1}^{n+1} \sin ((2 k-1) x)=\sum_{k=1}^{n} \sin ((2 k-1) x)+\sin ((2 n+1) x)=\frac{\sin ^{2}(n x)}{\sin x}+\sin ((2 n+1) x)= \\
=\frac{\sin ^{2}(n x)+\sin (2 n x+x) \sin x}{\sin x}=\frac{\sin ^{2}(n x)+\sin (2 n x) \cos x \sin x+\cos (2 n x) \sin ^{2} x}{\sin x}= \\
=\frac{\sin ^{2}(n x)+2 \sin (n x) \cos (n x) \cos x \sin x+\left(\cos ^{2}(n x)-\sin ^{2}(n x)\right) \sin ^{2} x}{\sin x}= \\
=\frac{\sin ^{2}(n x) \cos ^{2} x+2 \sin (n x) \cos (n x) \cos x \sin x+\cos ^{2}(n x) \sin ^{2} x}{\sin x}= \\
=\frac{(\sin (n x) \cos (x)+\cos n x \sin x)^{2}}{\sin x}=\frac{\sin ^{2}((n+1) x)}{\sin x}
\end{gathered}
$$

Second formula. Base case $n=1: \cos x=\frac{\sin 2 x}{2 \sin x}$ - a true statement.

Inductive step: Assume the statement is true for some $n$, we will prove that it is also true for $n+1$.

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sum_{k=1}^{n+1} \cos ((2 k-1) x)=\sum_{k=1}^{n} \cos ((2 k-1) x)+\cos ((2 n+1) x)=\frac{\sin (2 n x)}{2 \sin x}+\cos ((2 n+1) x)= \\
=\frac{\sin (2 n x)+2 \cos (2 n x+x) \sin x}{2 \sin x}=\frac{\sin (2 n x)+2 \cos (2 n x) \cos x \sin x-2 \sin (2 n x) \sin ^{2} x}{2 \sin x}= \\
=\frac{\sin (2 n x)\left(1-2 \sin ^{2} x\right)+\cos (2 n x) \sin 2 x}{2 \sin x}=\frac{\sin (2 n x) \cos (2 x)+\cos (2 n x) \sin 2 x}{2 \sin x}=\frac{\sin (2(n+1) x)}{2 \sin x}
\end{gathered}
$$

First, consider the case $\sin x=0$. In this case, the left side of the equation becomes 0, while the right side is 1008 or -1008, i.e., the numbers $x=\pi k$ for integer $k$ are not solutions to the problem.

Using the formulas proven above, we transform the original equation into $\frac{\sin ^{2} 1008 x}{\sin x}=\frac{\sin 1008 x \cos 1008 x}{\sin x}$, from which $\sin 1008 x=0$ or $\sin 1008 x=\cos 1008 x$.

In the first case, we get $1008 x=\pi k, k \in \mathbb{Z}$, hence $x=\frac{\pi k}{1008}, k \in \mathbb{Z}$. Since $\sin x \neq 0$, the number $k$ does not divide 1008.

In the second case, we get $1008 x=\frac{\pi}{4}+\pi k, k \in \mathbb{Z}$, hence $x=\frac{\pi+4 \pi k}{4032}, k \in \mathbb{Z}$. For these numbers, $\sin x \neq 0$, so no numbers need to be excluded from this set of solutions.
informal_statement:
7. (4 points) Solve the equation:

$$
\sin x + \sin 3x + \ldots + \sin 2015x = \cos x + \cos 3x + \ldots + \cos 2015x
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 7. (4 points) Solve the equation:

$$
\sin x + \sin 3x + \ldots + \sin 2015x = \cos x + \cos 3x + \ldots + \cos 2015x
$$ -/
theorem algebra_217566 {x : ℝ} :
  ∑ k ∈ Finset.range 2015, sin ((k + 1) * x) =
  ∑ k ∈ Finset.range 2015, cos ((k + 1) * x) ↔
  ∃ k : ℤ, x = π / 1008 + k * π := by

soln_description:
To solve this problem, we need to understand the structure of the islands and the ferry connections. The key is to analyze the condition for the existence of a ferry between two islands \(D_i\) and \(D_j\).

1. **Condition for Ferry Connection**:
   The problem states that there is a one-way ferry from \(D_i\) to \(D_j\) if and only if \(ij \equiv ia \pmod{n}\). This can be simplified as:
   \[
   ij \equiv ia \pmod{n} \implies j \equiv a \pmod{n}
   \]
   This means that for any island \(D_i\), there is a ferry to another island \(D_j\) if and only if \(j \equiv a \pmod{n}\).

2. **Coprime Condition**:
   Since \(a\) is coprime with \(n\), \(a\) has an inverse modulo \(n\). This implies that the mapping \(i \mapsto ai \pmod{n}\) is a permutation of the set \(\{1, 2, \ldots, n\}\).

3. **Cycle Structure**:
   The permutation induced by \(i \mapsto ai \pmod{n}\) can be decomposed into disjoint cycles. Each cycle represents a sequence of islands that can be visited starting from any island in that cycle.

4. **Maximum Number of Islands**:
   The maximum number of islands a tourist can visit corresponds to the length of the longest cycle in the permutation. The length of the longest cycle is determined by the order of \(a\) modulo \(n\), which is the smallest positive integer \(k\) such that \(a^k \equiv 1 \pmod{n}\).

5. **Function \(\gamma(n)\)**:
   The function \(\gamma(n)\) is defined based on the prime factorization of \(n\). Specifically, if \(n\) has the form \(n = 2^{\alpha} p_1 p_2 \cdots p_i p_{i+1}^{\alpha_{i+1}} \cdots p_m^{\alpha_m}\) with \(\alpha_{i+1}, \ldots, \alpha_m \geq 2\), then:
   \[
   \gamma(n) = \begin{cases}
   3m - i & \text{if } \alpha = 0 \\
   3m - i + 1 & \text{if } \alpha = 1 \\
   3m - i + 3 & \text{if } \alpha \geq 2
   \end{cases}
   \]
   This function \(\gamma(n)\) essentially counts the number of distinct prime factors and their exponents to determine the structure of the cycles.

6. **Conclusion**:
   The maximum number of islands a tourist can visit is given by \(1 + \gamma(n)\).

The final answer is \(\boxed{1 + \gamma(n)}\).
informal_statement:
Given the integer $n\geq 2$ and a integer ${a}$, which is coprime with ${n}$. A country has ${n}$ islands $D_1$, $D_2$, $\cdots$, $D_n$. For any $1\leq i\neq j\leq n$, there is a one-way ferry $D_i$ to $D_j$ if and only if $ij\equiv ia\pmod n$. A tourist can initially fly to any of the islands, and then he can only take a one-way ferry. What is the maximum number of islands he can visit?

[i]Created by Zhenhua Qu[/i]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Given the integer $n\geq 2$ and a integer ${a}$, which is coprime with ${n}$. A country has ${n}$ islands $D_1$, $D_2$, $\cdots$, $D_n$. For any $1\leq i\neq j\leq n$, there is a one-way ferry $D_i$ to $D_j$ if and only if $ij\equiv ia\pmod n$. A tourist can initially fly to any of the islands, and then he can only take a one-way ferry. What is the maximum number of islands he can visit?

[i]Created by Zhenhua Qu[/i] -/
theorem number_theory_33665 (n : ℕ) (hn : 2 ≤ n) (a : ℤ) (ha : IsCoprime a n) :
    IsGreatest {k | ∃ s : Finset ℕ, s.card = k ∧ ∀ i ∈ s, ∀ j ∈ s, i ≠ j → i * j ≡ i * a [ZMOD n]} (1 + (Nat.divisors n).card) := by

soln_description:
[Solution] Let the two roots of the equation be $x_{1}, x_{2}$, then $x_{1}>2$ and $x_{2}>2$.
Let $y=x-2$, i.e., $x=y+2$ substituted into the original equation gives

i.e.,
$$
\begin{array}{c}
(y+2)^{2}+(m-1)(y+2)+4-m=0, \\
y^{2}+(m+3) y+m+6=0 .
\end{array}
$$
$\because$ The two roots of the original equation are both greater than 2, then the two roots of $\circledast$ are both greater than 0. Thus $\left\{\begin{array}{l}\Delta=(m+3)^{2}-4(m+6) \geqslant 0, \\ m+3>0 .\end{array}\right.$ Solving gives $\quad\left\{\begin{array}{l}m \geqslant 3 \text { or } m \leqslant-5, \\ m>-3 .\end{array}\right.$ $\therefore \quad-6<m \leqslant-5$.
Therefore, the answer is $(B)$.
informal_statement:
$2 \cdot 63$ If the roots of the equation $x^{2}+(m-1) x+4-m=0$ are both greater than 2, then the range of values for $m$ is
(A) $m \leqslant-6$.
(B) $-6<m \leqslant-5$.
(C) $m<-3$.
(D) $m<-6$ or $-6<m \leqslant-5$.
(China Hubei Province Huanggang Region Junior High School Mathematics Competition, 1989)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $2 \cdot 63$ If the roots of the equation $x^{2}+(m-1) x+4-m=0$ are both greater than 2, then the range of values for $m$ is
(A) $m \leqslant-6$.
(B) $-6<m \leqslant-5$.
(C) $m<-3$.
(D) $m<-6$ or $-6<m \leqslant-5$.
(China Hubei Province Huanggang Region Junior High School Mathematics Competition, 1989) -/
theorem algebra_215062 (m : ℝ) (h : ∀ x : ℝ, x^2 + (m - 1) * x + 4 - m = 0 → x > 2) :
    -6 < m ∧ m ≤ -5 := by

soln_description:
1. Let \( a = gx \) and \( b = gy \), where \( g = \gcd(a, b) \) and \( \gcd(x, y) = 1 \). This means \( a \) and \( b \) are multiples of \( g \) and \( x \) and \( y \) are coprime.
2. Substitute \( a \) and \( b \) into the given equation:
   \[
   \frac{k}{2013} \cdot g(x + y) = \text{lcm}(a, b)
   \]
   Since \( \text{lcm}(a, b) = \frac{ab}{\gcd(a, b)} = \frac{gx \cdot gy}{g} = gxy \), we have:
   \[
   \frac{k}{2013} \cdot g(x + y) = gxy
   \]
3. Simplify the equation by dividing both sides by \( g \):
   \[
   \frac{k}{2013} \cdot (x + y) = xy
   \]
4. Rearrange to solve for \( k \):
   \[
   \frac{k}{2013} = \frac{xy}{x + y}
   \]
   Note that \( \gcd(xy, x + y) = 1 \) because \( x \) and \( y \) are coprime. Therefore, \( \frac{xy}{x + y} \) is in its simplest form.
5. For \( \frac{k}{2013} \) to be an integer, \( x + y \) must be a divisor of 2013. Let \( d = x + y \). Then \( d \mid 2013 \).
6. Each divisor \( d \) of 2013 corresponds to pairs \( (x, y) \) such that \( x + y = d \). The number of such pairs is given by Euler's totient function \( \phi(d) \), but since \( (x, y) \) and \( (y, x) \) are considered the same, we count each pair only once:
   \[
   \frac{\phi(d)}{2}
   \]
7. Sum over all divisors \( d \) of 2013, excluding \( d = 1 \) because \( x + y = 1 \) does not yield positive integers \( x \) and \( y \):
   \[
   \sum_{1 < d \mid 2013} \frac{\phi(d)}{2}
   \]
8. Calculate the total number of values of \( k \):
   \[
   \sum_{d \mid 2013} \frac{\phi(d)}{2} - \frac{\phi(1)}{2}
   \]
   Since \( \phi(1) = 1 \):
   \[
   \sum_{d \mid 2013} \frac{\phi(d)}{2} - \frac{1}{2}
   \]
9. The sum of \( \phi(d) \) over all divisors \( d \) of 2013 is 2013 (a property of Euler's totient function):
   \[
   \sum_{d \mid 2013} \phi(d) = 2013
   \]
   Therefore:
   \[
   \sum_{d \mid 2013} \frac{\phi(d)}{2} = \frac{2013}{2}
   \]
10. Subtract \(\frac{1}{2}\) to exclude the case \( d = 1 \):
    \[
    \frac{2013}{2} - \frac{1}{2} = 1006
    \]

The final answer is \(\boxed{1006}\)
informal_statement: How many positive integers $k$ are there such that \[\dfrac k{2013}(a+b)=lcm(a,b)\] has a solution in positive integers $(a,b)$?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- How many positive integers $k$ are there such that \[\dfrac k{2013}(a+b)=lcm(a,b)\] has a solution in positive integers $(a,b)$? -/
theorem number_theory_54338 :
    Set.ncard {k : ℕ | ∃ a b : ℕ, a > 0 ∧ b > 0 ∧ (k : ℚ) / 2013 * (a + b) = Nat.lcm a b} = 1006 := by

informal_statement:

A: $\frac{1}{4}$
B: $\frac{1}{2}$
C: $\frac{3}{4}$
D: 1
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Given in $\bigtriangleup ABC$, a, b, c are the lengths of the three sides, and $a^{2}-12b^{2}-c^{2}+4ab+8bc=0$, then the value of $\frac{b}{a+c}$ is (       ).

A: $\frac{1}{4}$
B: $\frac{1}{2}$
C: $\frac{3}{4}$
D: 1 -/
theorem algebra_8219 {a b c : ℝ} (ha : a > 0) (hb : b > 0) (hc : c > 0)
(h : a^2 - 12 * b^2 - c^2 + 4 * a * b + 8 * b * c = 0) : b / (a + c) = 1 / 2 := by

soln_description:
$$
\begin{aligned}
S & =6 \cdot\left(\mathrm{C}_{21}^{3}+\mathrm{C}_{22}^{3}+\cdots+\mathrm{C}_{2001}^{3}\right) \\
& =6\left[\left(\mathrm{C}_{3}^{3}+\mathrm{C}_{4}^{3}+\cdots+\mathrm{C}_{2001}^{3}\right)-\left(\mathrm{C}_{3}^{3}+\mathrm{C}_{4}^{3}+\cdots+\mathrm{C}_{20}^{3}\right)\right] \\
& =6 \cdot\left(\mathrm{C}_{2002}^{4}-\mathrm{C}_{21}^{4}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The translation is as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
S & =6 \cdot\left(\mathrm{C}_{21}^{3}+\mathrm{C}_{22}^{3}+\cdots+\mathrm{C}_{2001}^{3}\right) \\
& =6\left[\left(\mathrm{C}_{3}^{3}+\mathrm{C}_{4}^{3}+\cdots+\mathrm{C}_{2001}^{3}\right)-\left(\mathrm{C}_{3}^{3}+\mathrm{C}_{4}^{3}+\cdots+\mathrm{C}_{20}^{3}\right)\right] \\
& =6 \cdot\left(\mathrm{C}_{2002}^{4}-\mathrm{C}_{21}^{4}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$
informal_statement: 25. 2. 3 * Sum: $S=19 \cdot 20 \cdot 21+20 \cdot 21 \cdot 22+\cdots+1999 \cdot 2000 \cdot 2001$.
informal_proof:
We are asked to verify the equality:
$$ \sum_{i=19}^{1999} i \cdot (i+1) \cdot (i+2) = 6 \cdot \left(\binom{2002}{4} - \binom{21}{4}\right) $$
The sum on the left-hand side consists of terms of the form $i(i+1)(i+2)$. We can express this product in terms of binomial coefficients using the identity $k(k+1)(k+2) = 6 \binom{k+2}{3}$.
Applying this identity to each term in the sum, we transform the left-hand side as follows:
$$ \sum_{i=19}^{1999} i \cdot (i+1) \cdot (i+2) = \sum_{i=19}^{1999} 6 \binom{i+2}{3} $$
We can factor out the constant 6 from the sum:
$$ = 6 \sum_{i=19}^{1999} \binom{i+2}{3} $$
To simplify this sum, let $j = i+2$. As $i$ ranges from $19$ to $1999$, $j$ ranges from $19+2=21$ to $1999+2=2001$. The sum becomes:
$$ = 6 \sum_{j=21}^{2001} \binom{j}{3} $$
Now we use the hockey-stick identity, which states that for any $n \ge r \ge 0$, $\sum_{k=r}^{n} \binom{k}{r} = \binom{n+1}{r+1}$. To apply this identity, we need the sum to start from the lower index of the binomial coefficient, which is 3. We can rewrite the sum by including the terms from $j=3$ to $j=20$ and then subtracting them:
$$ \sum_{j=21}^{2001} \binom{j}{3} = \left(\sum_{j=3}^{2001} \binom{j}{3}\right) - \left(\sum_{j=3}^{20} \binom{j}{3}\right) $$
Applying the hockey-stick identity to the first summation, with $n=2001$ and $r=3$:
$$ \sum_{j=3}^{2001} \binom{j}{3} = \binom{2001+1}{3+1} = \binom{2002}{4} $$
Applying the hockey-stick identity to the second summation, with $n=20$ and $r=3$:
$$ \sum_{j=3}^{20} \binom{j}{3} = \binom{20+1}{3+1} = \binom{21}{4} $$
Substituting these results back, the sum simplifies to:
$$ \sum_{j=21}^{2001} \binom{j}{3} = \binom{2002}{4} - \binom{21}{4} $$
Therefore, the original sum is equal to:
$$ 6 \left(\binom{2002}{4} - \binom{21}{4}\right) $$
This confirms the given equality.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 25. 2. 3 * Sum: $S=19 \cdot 20 \cdot 21+20 \cdot 21 \cdot 22+\cdots+1999 \cdot 2000 \cdot 2001$. -/
theorem algebra_141057 : ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 19 1999, i * (i + 1) * (i + 2) = 6 * (Nat.choose 2002 4 - Nat.choose 21 4) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_141057 : ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 19 1999, i * (i + 1) * (i + 2) = 6 * (Nat.choose 2002 4 - Nat.choose 21 4) := by 
  native_decide

soln_description:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)}-\sqrt{n^{6}-1}}{n}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\left(\sqrt{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)}-\sqrt{n^{6}-1}\right)\left(\sqrt{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)}+\sqrt{n^{6}-1}\right)}{n\left(\sqrt{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)}+\sqrt{n^{6}-1}\right)}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)-\left(n^{6}-1\right)}{n\left(\sqrt{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)}+\sqrt{n^{6}-1}\right)}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n^{6}-n^{4}+n^{2}-1-n^{6}+1}{n\left(\sqrt{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)}+\sqrt{n^{6}-1}\right)}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{-n^{4}+n^{2}}{n\left(\sqrt{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)}+\sqrt{n^{6}-1}\right)}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\frac{1}{n^{4}}\left(-n^{4}+n^{2}\right)}{\frac{1}{n^{4}} n\left(\sqrt{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)}+\sqrt{n^{6}-1}\right)}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{-1+\frac{1}{n^{2}}}{\frac{1}{n^{3}} \sqrt{\left(n^{4}+1\right)\left(n^{2}-1\right)}+\frac{1}{n^{3}} \sqrt{n^{6}-1}}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{-1+\frac{1}{n^{2}}}{\sqrt{\left(1+\frac{1}{n^{4}}\right)\left(1-\frac{1}{n^{2}}\right)}+\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{n^{6}}}}=\frac{-1+0}{\sqrt{(1+0)(1-0)}+\sqrt{1-0}}=-\frac{1}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

## Problem Kuznetsov Limits 5-23
